instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze and ASD give error on Sensor-current(IDOR)--DC In (test1) ERROR- Sensor is reading below the low limit

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: That sensor is likely because you didn’t have the charger plugged in. Which board is this 3332 3662 3787 or 2015?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Is that sensor on I/O power board ?

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Need board model! A sensor will not cause freezes. I bet this is a 3662 or 3787.....

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Its <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Make sure your LCD is good. Seen a ton of these gen1 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> units that had bad LCD panels that mimicked a hard system freeze (cursor freezes, etc). Sometimes it would be from motion/movement of the display, other times it seemed to be random. Tricked a ton of our retail customers (would "swear" it's a board issue, but it was a panel failing). Won't necessarily have any sort of display anomaly (lines or weird colors or anything) or trip AHT/ASD failure, etc.

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Dont have another screen to test but screen itself looks ok

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: Solved ,someone was reflow memory and knock out one capacitor

threads.title: Macbook Pro 15 <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> sometimes freeze
threads.message: They reflowed the RAM because it was freezing. One decoupling cap will usually not matter at all. Which cap was it?
